description: This course introduces students to the subject of machine learning. The primary focus is the development and application of powerful machine learning algorithms applied to complex, real-world data. Topics covered include linear regression, nearest neighbor models, k-means clustering, shrinkage methods, decision trees and forests, boosting, bagging, support vector machines, and hierarchical clustering. Applications are taken from a wide variety of disciplines, including biology, economics, public policy, public health, and sports. Offered annually during fall and spring semester. Counts toward computer science and mathematics majors and statistics and data science concentration. Prerequisite: SDS 164 or SDS 264 or permission of the instructor.
name: Algorithms for Decision Making
notes: You may not register concurrently for both SDS 341 and SDS 333.
Not open to first-year or sophomore students.
prerequisites: SDS 164 or SDS 264 or permission of the instructor.
